titleStmt.title: Moral judgments are (most probably) robust to physical fatigue: evidence from Process Dissociation analyses in athletes and firefighters

analytic.title: Moral judgments are (most probably) robust to physical fatigue: evidence from Process Dissociation analyses in athletes and firefighters

abstract.p: Across two experiments, we examined the effect of physical fatigue on moral decision-making. A total sample of N = 303 participants was subjected to acute physical exercise. Half of the participants were presented with moral dilemmas before the physical exercise, and the other half after the exercise. We measured moral judgement using a shortened version of the Process Dissociation procedure, allowing us to investigate: (1) decisions in the traditional sacrificial dilemmas and (2) deontological and utilitarian moral inclinations. The results showed that physical fatigue had no significant effect on moral judgements in nine out of ten statistical tests. This suggests a unique resilience of moral judgments to physical fatigue, in contrast to what is known about cognitive fatigue. All data and materials, data are available at https://osf.io/musc8/?view_only=328aee8087dd4203a9a576e350b12327.

div.head: Moral judgments are (most probably) robust to physical fatigue: evidence from Process
div.p: Dissociation analyses in athletes and firefighters.

Moral decisions often require balancing harm to individuals against broader societal benefits. Educational institutions may fail students to maintain academic standards; justice systems incarcerate individuals to protect society. These decisions reflect two philosophical traditions: deontology, which emphasizes inviolable moral rules, and utilitarianism, which focuses on maximizing overall benefits. People's moral decisions can be classified along those philosophies so that their actions can be seen as deontological or utilitarian. However, moral decision-making is context-dependent; a person acting consistently with utilitarianism does not have to consciously endorse utilitarian philosophy or does not necessarily make similar judgments in analogous differences in the future (e.g., Gawronski et al., 2018;Schein, 2020).
Rather, to understand and predict moral decision-making, research identifies nonphilosophical factors affecting it.

One such factor is fatigue. One famous study showed that tired and hungry judges in Israeli parole boards tend to provide fewer favourable decisions (Danziger et al., 2011). It has been later heavily criticised for methodological reasons (Glöckner, 2016;Weinshall-Margel & Shapard, 2011), but this is not the point here. Rather, the mainmuch broader -point is the appealing idea that our (moral) decision-making is easily malleable, context-dependent, and out of our full control. Many such claims are based on weak and often non-replicable evidence from priming studies, where subtle cues are reported to have large effects on human judgment and decision-making (Mac Giolla et al., 2024). For example, a now-retracted study reported that participants standing on a higher stage vs. ground poured less hot sauce on meals prepared for other participants (Sanna et al., 2011). This change in the dosing of hot sauce was interpreted as evidence that the vertical position of an agent cues elevated moral judgments . However, lay observation suggests otherwisepeople tend to reveal similar preferences not only throughout the day but often across their entire lives (Urminsky, 2021).
So, what is the experimental evidence for fatigue effects on moral judgments? And, more
broadly, to what extent is moral decision-making malleable by accidental contextual factors?

Conflicting evidence emerges from studies focused on the relationship between fatigue and moral judgments. Experimentally induced fatigue led to a greater aversion toward utilitarian choices in a subset of moral dilemmas (Timmons & Byrne, 2019), while long-term, environmentally-induced fatigue led to a greater preference toward utilitarian choices (Zheng et al., 2023). Yet, in another study, Weippert and colleagues (2018) had their participants perform an acute physical exercise, and subsequently, in a state of fatigue, made moral decisions. They found fewer utilitarian choices in tired participants.

Participants writing a paragraph without using letters a or n changed their moral behaviour: they became more inclined to engage in unethical behaviour of low societal consensus, but less inclined to engage in unethical behaviour of high societal consensus (Yam et al., 2014). So, fatigue can increase or decrease dishonesty. In a longitudinal study of Marine Corps martial arts training the authors found the soldiers had significantly impaired decision-making immediately after the extremely demanding (thus, tiring) training (Siedlik et al., 2022). Furthermore, they found the marines' moral intention and moral judgement to worsen throughout the training programme, pointing out that it may lead to impaired ethical decision-making in real-life combat.
Why would one even expect fatigue to affect moral judgments? At least two mechanisms were proposed: limited cognitive resources and increased testosterone levels.

Fatigue compromises cognitive processing (Abd-Elfattah et al., 2015;Almonroeder et al., 2020). Tired people have fewer cognitive resources they can invest in decision-making, leading to shallower processing of available information, which in turn leads to sub-optimal choices, functioning, and performance (Cao et al., 2022;Harris & Bray, 2019;Kunrath et al., 2020). Being cognitively fatigued is linked with deteriorated physical exercise-related decision-making (Fortes et al., 2023), or greater difficulties in making decisions generally (Killgore et al., 2007). For instance, fatigued individuals avoid risky decisions (Jia et al., 2022;Lu-Lu & Yong-Juan, 2012), and their economic decision-making may become less consistent, and thus less accurate (Mullette-Gillman et al., 2015).

Another reason to expect that fatigue may affect moral judgments, is that acute physical exercise elevates testosterone levels (Crewther et al., 2014;Kowal et al., 2020Kowal et al., , 2021, which in turn can be related to more utilitarian decisions (Armbruster et al., 2021;Carney & Mason, 2010). However, also this evidence is mixedother studies report testosterone administration increased sensitivity to moral norms (Brannon et al., 2019), or no effects at all (Arnocky et al., 2017;Reynolds et al., 2021).

On top of mixed evidence across studies reporting the effects of fatigue, many of them have small sample sizes. For example, the two experiments directly studying physical fatigue had samples of N = 55 (Siedlik et al., 2022), and N = 32 (Weippert et al., 2018). Critically, the accuracy of the operationalisation of moral decision-making is questionable (Kahane, 2015).

That is, moral dilemmas used in prior research pit deontological against utilitarian solutions, artificially making them negatively correlated. For example, a famous trolley dilemma used in this line of research (Foot, 1967) asks people whether it is permissible to redirect a trolley from tracks with five people to side tracks, where there is a single person. Deontology suggests harming people is never permissible, thus this action is immoral. Utilitarianism suggests five lives are more valuable than one, thus, the action is moral. A person who decided for one solution is classified as opposing the other one. Although depicted as contradictory, both of those motives are independent and often consistent and often both cue the same behaviour (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). For example, moral identity positively correlates to deontology and utilitarianism (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). Both inclinations negatively predict investment in sin stocks (Niszczota et al., 2022(Niszczota et al., , 2024 and positively predict willingness to self-sacrifice for the benefit of others (Muda et al., 2024). So, if fatigue decreases or increases both inclinations we would miss this in traditional moral dilemmas since these changes would cancel each other out.

To solve this issue, we adopted a Process Dissociation procedure (Conway & Gawronski, 2013), which allows us to estimate both moral inclinations independently, along with the traditional score of utilitarian choices made in incongruent scenarios, i.e., where deontological and utilitarian motives are antithetic. The battery designed to test the two inclinations consists of two types of sacrificial scenarios: congruent (where deontological and utilitarian inclinations cue the same decision of rejecting the action), and incongruent (where utilitarian inclinations cues endorsement of an action but deontological inclination rejects the action). For example, one is asked whether it is permissible to torture a person suspected of planning a terrorist attack that may kill hundreds of people (incongruent), or a person suspected of planning a prank with bombs filled with paint (congruent). The idea is that deontological considerations always prevent torture, whereas utilitarian considerations permit torture only in the former case because only there the benefits justify the means. Details of the computational procedure can be found in the Supplementary Materials, but in short, we first calculate the average endorsement rates in congruent (Actcon) and incongruent dilemmas(Actincon). The U-parameter, conceptualised as capturing the inclination to make decisions consistent with utilitarian (i.e., outcome-maximizing) principles is estimated with a simple formula
So, a person who endorses all actions where the sacrifice is beneficial (Actcon = 1), but endorses no actions where the sacrifice is not beneficial (Actincon = 0), has the U-parameter equal to:
The D-parameter, conceptualised as capturing the inclination to make decisions consistent with deontological principles is calculated by the following formula:

Note, that this formula does not allow calculating the D-parameter for a fullyutilitarian person, because for them the denominator is equal to zero. Both D and Uparameters are standardised. In most studies, the D and U-parameters are either not correlated (Białek et al., 2021;Byrd & Conway, 2019;Conway & Gawronski, 2013), or weakly positively correlated (Muda et al., 2018;Niszczota et al., 2024), challenging the claim of their contradictory nature.

div.head: Transparency and Openness
div.p: We report how we determined our sample sizes, all data exclusions (if any), all manipulations, and all measures in the study, and we follow JARS from quantitative research (Appelbaum et al., 2018 We report two experiments, testing the effects of acute physical fatigue on moral judgments.

Experiment 1 reports a sample of N = 107 physical academy students, and Experiment 2 N = 196 firefighters during their annual physical exam. Both times, participants were randomly assigned to fill the PD battery before or after an acute physical exercise procedure. In both experiments, we jointly conducted 10 statistical tests (for both PD parameters and traditional utilitarian scores). We observed a significant change in only one of the tests, specifically

Experiment 2 showed a decrease in the D-parameter. Bayesian analysis either favours the null hypothesis compared to the alternative hypothesis or suggests inconsistent findings due e.g. limited statistical power.

div.head: Experiment 1
div.p: To test the hypothesis that physical fatigue is a predictor of certain shifts in moral decisionmaking, we implement the procedure from the previous studies that elicited testosterone through acute physical activity (Kowal et al., 2020(Kowal et al., , 2021, and provide the participants with a Process Dissociation measure of deontological and utilitarian choices (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). By recruiting a homogenous group of participants, our analyses narrow down possible effects of uncontrolled variables and provide decently powered results.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited and analysed the data from 107 volunteering male students 1 ( Mage=21.00, SD = 1.56) of a physical education academy. We remunerated them for their participation with a voucher worth the equivalent of ~10 USD in the local currency. A medical authority examined all participants and considered them physically healthy. The participants were obliged not to smoke or drink energetic or alcoholic beverages for 24 hours before entering the study. Feeling ill on the day of the study, having chronic diseases, and taking hormonal treatment or supplements were exclusion criteria. We did not determine the exact target sample size a priori but rather aimed for as much data (but aimed to recruit at least 100 participants) as possible within the lab availability time window. A sensitivity analysis indicated our sample (N = 107) provided 80% power to detect effects of d ≥ 0.55 at α = .05
(two-tailed). While this allows detection of only moderate-to-large effects, our sample was nearly triple that of previous studies in this area (e.g., N = 32 in Weippert et al., 2018).

Moreover, to account for limited statistical power, we additionally report Bayesian analysis, which weights the observed effect size and its estimation accuracy when comparing the support for the hypothesis against the null (Dienes & Mclatchie, 2017).

div.head: Measures
div.p: Moral judgments. To measure utilitarianism/deontology, we used the Process Dissociation procedure with 16 of the 20 original scenarios from Conway & Gawronski (2013). Following our preregistration, we omitted the four scenarios relating to abortion and animal testing, as in our prior studies, they showed unexpected patterns of responses. For example, Poles tended to not allow for abortion but to allow for animal testing in both congruent and incongruent scenarios (e.g., Muda et al., 2018). We also wanted to shorten the experiment to increase its feasibility. This change to the procedure can somewhat limit the power to reliably establish the parameters, yet some other experimental work on the topic also used shortened versions of the PD-battery, e.g., Gawronski et al., (2017) or Lee & Gino, (2015).

Fatigue. As a manipulation check, we measured participants' heart rate prior to, during, and after the acute physical exercise with a Polar RS400 cardio frequency meter strapped to the participants' chests.

Additional measures. We also measured two other variables unrelated to this research: risktaking (using a self-created set of lotteries) and disgust sensitivity (using a self-created Sounds of Disgust Scale, Disgust Scale- Revised, Olatunji et al., 2007, andThree Domains of Disgust Scale, Tybur et al., 2009). The order of the implemented tools was as follows: risk-taking assessment, Sounds of Disgust Scale, and then, depending on the group, either 16 Process Disassociation scenarios and the two remaining disgust sensitivity scales, or the other way round).

div.head: Procedure
div.p: The study took place in a laboratory, with all participants being tested between 8 and 11 a.m.

Each participant was randomly selected into one of two groupsthey either provided their answers to the moral dilemmas before the physical exercise or a few minutes after finishing exercising. The order of presentation of the dilemmas was randomized. We opted for a between-subject design because we wanted to avoid problems with memorizing the answers provided prior to the manipulation (e.g., participants may be inclined to consistify their responses). Moreover, because the scale involves multiple dilemmas, we thought answering them again could be tedious for participants.

In this study, we followed the exact procedure that previous studies of similar design (Crewther et al., 2014;Kowal et al., 2020Kowal et al., , 2021. We used a Monark cycle ergometer (824E, Sweden) for a sprint cycling exercise. The exact steps of the procedure were as follows: i) 5minute warm-up with a load of 2 kilograms, ii) one minute of resting, iii) 10-second sprint with a load of 7.5% of one's body mass, iv) 50 seconds of slow cycling without a load. Points iii) and iv) were then repeated four more times. Ultimately, after five cycles of 10-second sprints and 50-second slow cycling, the participants again cycled slowly for one minute without a load. This procedure is extremely exhausting, and the study was conducted in the presence of a qualified paramedic. Participants used tablets to respond to the Qualtrics questionnaires.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: First, we confirmed prior findings that the D and U-parameters are independent or only weakly correlated. Specifically, here r(105) = 0.20, p = .044. We also tested whether the cycling was in fact demanding and tiring by comparing heart rate prior and after the exercise.

We observed a large increase in the experimental group Mpre = 81.30 SD = 12.90; Mpost = 127.0, SD = 13.60, t(51) = -20.50, p < .001, d = -2.84 [-3.45, -2.22], showing that our manipulation did influence the physiological state of the participants. We then proceeded with testing the main hypothesis that physical fatigue will affect moral judgments.

As preregistered, we compared the deontological and utilitarian parameters between the pretreatment and post-treatment groups, using two two-tailed between-subject t-tests 2 . These parameters were calculated using a Process Dissociation procedure and standardised (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). For exploratory reasons, we also analysed the traditional score, i.e., utilitarian decisions made in incongruent sacrificial scenarios.

In all cases, we observed no significant differences (Table 1). Because non-significant results of a statistical test are never an evidence of the absence of an effect (e.g., we could have lacked statistical power, or the true effect is smaller than assumed), we decided to follow up this analysis with a Bayesian t-test. This approach allows us to compare relative evidence for the null against the alternative hypothesis. Using the default prior of Cauchy = 0.707 3 , we found moderate support for the null. In other words, it is about 5 times more likely to observe the current data if the null hypothesis is true, compared to when the alternative hypothesis is true. Note, however, that some statisticians claim the default prior is conservative and biased against small, true effects (Tendeiro & Kiers, 2019). Thus, some caution is advised when interpreting the Bayesian analysis. Note: Bayesian interpretation based on criteria developed by Lee and Wagenmakers (2014).

Study 1 showed moral judgments to be robust to physical fatiguewe did not find any differences in the D-parameter, U-parameter, and traditional scoring. However, given the relatively modest sample size, we conducted a follow-up study for a more robust conclusion.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited and analysed the data from 221 professionally active firefighters of the State Fire Service in Poland. They were not remunerated for their participation. They were all considered physically healthy by a medical authority, and they did not suffer from any chronic disease. The participants were obliged not to drink alcoholic beverages for 24 hours before entering the study. Feeling ill on the day of the study, failing a physical activity test (described in detail below) or having any missing values in the survey were the exclusion criteria. Although we preregistered to collect at least 200 records applicable for the analysis,

after the exclusions, we ended up with 196 individuals ( Mage=23.50, SD = 4.55). Our sample size had 80% power to detect the effects of fatigue of d = 0.40. To account for limited statistical power, and to repeat the exact analyses we performed in Study 1, we additionally report Bayesian analysis.

div.head: Measures
div.p: Moral judgments. Moral judgments were measured in the same way as in Experiment 1.

Fatigue. Due to the differences between the two experiments, in evoking the physical fatigue procedure (see below), in Experiment 2 it was not feasible to repeat the heart rate using the Polar RS400 cardio frequency meter. Thus, as a manipulation check, we measured participants' heart rates after the acute physical exercise with a finger Jumper JPD-500F pulse oximeter.

Additional measures. We also implemented the traditional trolley dilemmas in their indirect (pulling a lever) and direct versions (a push on a footbridge). Following Bostyn (Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Xu et al., 2024), we aimed to approximate deontological inclination with a question about the permissibility of inaction, and utilitarian inclination with a question about the permissibility of action. Moreover, for the sake of unrelated research, we again used a self-created set of lotteries to assess risk-taking, PANAS scale to assess positive and negative affect (Watson et al., 1988), and the Three Domains of Disgust Scale (Tybur et al., 2009). The fixed order of the implemented tools was as follows: PANAS, 16 PD dilemmas, traditional trolley dilemmas, risk-taking assessment, Three Domains of Disgust Scale).

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Half of the participants completed the 16-item Process Dissociation inventory, and then proceeded to the fitness test described below (pre-test group), while the other half first performed the fitness test and then completed the questionnaire (post-test group).

As part of the multi-stage fitness test, also known as the BEEP test, participants repeatedly cover a 20-meter-long and 1.5-meter-wide distance. Their task is to reach the end of the track before hearing a sound signal. Upon reaching the end, participants turn around and, after hearing the subsequent sound signal, run back along the same distance.

In the first iteration, participants must cover this distance seven times, each time in less than 9 seconds. Then, they must complete the distance eight times in 8 seconds, followed by eight times in 7.5 seconds, nine times in 7.2 seconds, nine times in 6.8 seconds, ten times in 6.5 seconds, ten times in 6.2 seconds, eleven times in 6 seconds, eleven times in 5.7 seconds, eleven times in 5.5 seconds, twelve times in 5.4 seconds, and finally five times in 5.1 seconds.

This consisted of at most about 12 minutes of running. If a participant fails to complete the distance within the required time twice in a row, the test is terminated. Importantly, passing this test was mandatory for participants to receive a positive evaluation in their professional assessment. In the State Fire Service in Poland, the minimum passing grade for men is achieved by running the distance five times in 6.2 seconds without committing two consecutive errors at any of the previous stages.
Participants took part in the test in groups of up to 20 people. As soon as a given participant completed the BEEP test, they approached the experimenter, where their pulse was measured.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: The physical exam produced a large increase in oximeter measures in the experimental group, We then tested the main hypothesis that physical fatigue will affect moral judgments.

As preregistered and consistent with Experiment 1, we compared the traditional score in sacrificial moral dilemmas and the D and U-parameters between the pre-treatment and posttreatment groups, using two two-tailed between-subject t-tests 4 . In all but one cases, we observed no significant differences, with D-parameter showing a slight decrease (t(194)=2.32, p=. 022, d=0.33 [0.05, 0.61]. As for the Bayesian analyses, they showed results ranging from inconclusive support for the effect (B10=1.87) to the conclusive support for the null (B01=5.35 (Table 1). Exploratory tests on the effects of fatigue on the permissibility of action and inaction also showed no significant effects (ps > .222, BF01 > 3.18).

Jointly, the results suggest no consistent or strong differences in moral judgments between fatigued and non-fatigued groups. Compared to Experiment 1, we doubled the sample size and supplemented the original procedure with a complimentary one. After these changes, we found null effects in six out of seven statistical tests. Consistently, Bayesian analysis classifies our results as either supporting the null or inconclusive. So, we interpret our results as consistent with Experiment 1, i.e. suggesting no causal effects of physical fatigue on moral judgments.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Our study found that acute physical fatigue does not affect moral judgments. is psychologically framed as a non-decision (Anderson, 2003), allowing individuals to avoid the psychological burden of active choice.

A more sophisticated methodological approach that addresses this limitation is CNI modeling (Gawronski et al., 2017) and its derivatives such as pro-CNI (Hennig & Hütter, 2021) or CAN (Liu & Liao, 2021). These frameworks, though not without their own limitations (see Baron & Goodwin, 2020), can quantify preference for inaction independently and potentially reveal effects of fatigue that our method could not detect. Furthermore, while our findings suggest that acute, short-duration physical fatigue does not significantly alter moral judgments, these results may not generalize to more prolonged physical exhaustion-such as that experienced by athletes after completing a marathon or firefighters at the end of a 16-hour shift battling intense fires. Future research should investigate these more enduring forms of physical fatigue, which may have different cognitive and physiological profiles. Additionally, a withinsubject experimental design would provide more direct evidence for the causal relationship between acute exercise and moral judgments by controlling for individual differences in baseline moral inclinations.

To sum up, we showed that participants who were acutely physically fatigued responded to hypothetical moral scenarios similarly to those who were rested, and display the same prominence of deontological and utilitarian inclinations. From a practical point of view, this is a good thing, because many people who make moral decisions (paramedics, doctors, firefighters, soldiers, police officers, etc.) are often tired. Their moral judgments should be immune to this state. From a theoretical point of view, we show that cognitive processes underlying moral judgments are not vulnerable to physical fatigue. This fits a version of the dual-process theory, in which both moral inclinations are produced intuitively (Bago & De Neys, 2019;Białek & De Neys, 2016, and reflection is employed only to solve potential internal conflict (Byrd & Conway, 2019). Finally, our results show that human cognition, at least in its moral aspect, is not as malleable as the psychological literature shows.

In other words moral judgments seem robust to the state of fatigue. In principle, we believe that the psychological literature may have been biased to show successful incidental manipulations on a wide range of behaviours, and in reality, the effects are smaller or do not exist at all (Simmons et al., 2011;Simonsohn, 2015). This is, however, only a speculation which warrants larger empirical research and replication projects (Zwaan et al., 2018).

You find a time machine and travel back to the year 1920. While checking into a hotel, you meet a young Austrian artist and veteran of the First World War. You realize this is Adolf Hitler before his rise to power in Nazi Germany. He is staying in the hotel room next to yours and the doors are not locked. It would be easy to simply smother him with a pillow in his sleep and disappear, stopping the Second World War and the Nazi party before they even start. However, he has not committed any crimes yet and it seems wrong to hurt an innocent person. Is it appropriate for you to kill an innocent young Hitler in order to prevent the Second World War?

2 Congruent Time Machine You find a time machine and travel back to the year 1920. While checking into a hotel, you meet a young petty criminal. You realize this is George Brackman, a man who later on abducted a child and held her for a week until her family paid him some ransom money. He is staying in the hotel room next to yours and the doors are not locked. It would be easy to simply smother him with a pillow in his sleep and disappear, stopping the abduction and ransom demands before they even start. However, he has not committed any crimes yet and it seems wrong to hurt an innocent person. Is it appropriate for you to kill George Brackman in order to prevent him from taking a child hostage?
3 Incongruent Car Accident

You are driving through a busy city street when all of a sudden a young mother carrying a child trips and falls into the path of your vehicle. You are going too fast to brake in time; your only hope is to swerve out of the way. Unfortunately, the only place you can swerve is currently occupied by a little old lady. If you swerve to avoid the young mother and baby, you will seriously injure or kill the old lady. Is it appropriate to swerve and hit the old lady in order to avoid the young mother and child?
4 Congruent Car Accident

You are driving through a busy city street when all of a sudden a young mother carrying a child trips and falls into the path of your vehicle. You are going too fast to brake in time; your only hope is to swerve out of the way. Unfortunately, the only place you can swerve is currently occupied by a group of children on their way to elementary school. If you swerve to avoid the young mother and baby, you will seriously injure or kill several of them. Is it appropriate to swerve and hit the schoolchildren in order to avoid the young mother and child?

div.head: Incongruent Hard Times
div.p: You are the head of a poor household in a developing country. Your crops have failed for the second year in a row, and it appears that you have no way to feed your family. Your sons, ages eight and ten, are too young to go off to the city where there are jobs, but your daughter could fare better. You know a man from your village who lives in the city and who makes sexually explicit films featuring girls such as your daughter. In front of your daughter, he tells you that in one year of working in his studio your daughter could earn enough money to keep your family fed for several growing seasons.
Is it appropriate for you to employ your daughter in the pornography industry in order to feed your family?
6 Congruent Hard Times

You are the head of a poor household in a developing country. Your sons, ages eight and ten, work on the family farm every day in order to teach them the value of hard work and providing for others. Your daughter, however, cannot work on the farm due to the heavy lifting required. You worry that she will not learn the value of money if she does not work. You know a man from your village who lives in the city and who makes sexually explicit films featuring girls such as your daughter. In front of your daughter, he tells you that in one year of working in his studio your daughter could earn enough money to keep your family fed for several growing seasons. Is it appropriate for you to employ your daughter in the pornography industry in order to teach her the value of money?
7 Incongruent Crying Baby
It is war time. Enemy soldiers have taken over your village. They have orders to kill all remaining civilians. You and some of your townspeople have sought refuge in the cellar of a large house.

Outside you hear the voices of soldiers who have come to search the house for valuables. A baby with no parents begins to cry loudly. You cover her mouth to block the sound. If you remove your hand from the baby's mouth her crying will summon the attention of the soldiers who will kill you and the others hiding out in the cellar. To save yourself and the others you must smother the child to death. Is it appropriate for you to smother the child in order to save yourself and the other townspeople from being killed?

8 Congruent Crying Baby It is war time. Enemy soldiers have taken over your village. They have orders to capture all remaining civilians to make them work quarrying stone in a mine. You and some of your townspeople have sought refuge in the cellar of a large house. Outside you hear the voices of soldiers who have come to search the house for valuables. A baby with no parents begins to cry loudly. You cover her mouth to block the sound. If you remove your hand from her mouth the crying will summon the attention of the soldiers who will capture you and the others hiding out in the cellar. To save yourself and the others from laboring in the mine you must smother the child to death. Is it appropriate for you to smother the child in order to save yourself and the other townspeople from being captured?

9 Incongruent Relationship You are divorced now and your former spouse lives far away. You don't expect to see your former spouse for a very long time. However, you have recently started dating a new person that is positively wonderful. Your new partner is head over heels in love for the first time and you feel equally strong about your partner. You want to do everything in your power to keep the relationship progressing smoothly to what you believe will be a second marriage. Unfortunately, your new partner has told you many times that dating someone who is divorced is totally unacceptable. It is expressly forbidden in your partner's religion. Your partner doesn't know about your ex-spouse. You consider simply pretending that you have never been divorced so that your current relationship can continue. Is it appropriate for you to leave your new partner in the dark about your previous relationship in order to keep her/him happy and the relationship alive?

You are divorced now and your former spouse lives far away. You don't expect to see your former spouse for a very long time. However, you have recently started dating a new person that is positively wonderful. Your new partner is head over heels in love for the first time and you feel equally strong about your partner. You want to do everything in your power to keep the relationship progressing smoothly to what you believe will be a second marriage. Unfortunately, your ex-spouse gave you a very serious and incurable Sexually Transmitted Disease (STD). Your partner does not know about it. You consider simply pretending that you don't know about the STD so that your current relationship can continue. Is it appropriate for you to leave your new partner in the dark about your STD in order to keep her/him happy and the relationship alive?

11 Incongruent Abortion You are a surgeon. A young woman you know becomes pregnant, but her body reacts in an unusual fashion. She develops a severe case of preeclampsia, a dangerous syndrome that leads to rapid increases in blood pressure. The only treatment is to deliver the baby. Unless the baby is delivered soon, the mother will die. However, the baby is too young to survive on its own. If it is delivered, it will die. So, although it is very difficult for her, the mother asks you to abort the baby. Is it appropriate for you to perform an abortion in order to save the mother's life?

12 Congruent Abortion You are a surgeon. A young woman you know becomes pregnant, but she is not yet ready for children. She has not finished high school, has no income, and was abandoned by the father. If she has the baby now, she will be stuck as a single mother on welfare for the rest of her life. This will make things very hard on her and the baby. She thinks that it would be smarter to wait and have children later. So, although it is very difficult for her, she asks you to abort the baby. Is it appropriate for you to perform an abortion in order to let the mother live a better life?
13 Incongruent Torture

You are a police officer, and have recently caught a criminal you have been hunting for some time. He is allegedly responsible for rigging a series of explosive devices: some that have already gone off and some that have yet to detonate. He places explosives outside city cafes and sets them to go off at a time when people are drinking coffee on the patios. In this manner, he has injured many people and might injure many more. Now that the criminal is in custody, you want to know where the unexploded bombs are so you can defuse them. He refuses to talk, so you decide to use "aggressive interrogation techniques" like holding his head under water and beating him. Is it appropriate for you to use "aggressive interrogation techniques" in order to find and defuse the unexploded bombs?

14 Congruent Torture You are a police officer, and have recently caught a criminal you have been hunting for some time. He is allegedly responsible for rigging a series of explosive devices: some that have already gone off and some that have yet to detonate. He places explosives outside city cafes and sets them to go off at a time when no one is around. His explosives are inside paint cans so that they spray nearby objects with paint. In this manner, he has sprayed many cafes with paint and might spray many more. Now that the criminal is in custody, you want to know where the unexploded bombs are so you can defuse them. He refuses to talk, so you decide to use "aggressive interrogation techniques" like holding his head under water and beating him. Is it appropriate for you to use "aggressive interrogation techniques" in order to find and defuse the unexploded bombs?

You are a doctor in a health clinic overrun by patients with a serious disease. You just received a shipment of drugs that can cure the disease but the drugs have their own severe side-effects. If you administer the drugs to your patients, a small number will die from the side effects but most will live. If you do not, most will die from the disease. Is it appropriate for you to administer the drug to your patients?
16 Congruent Vaccine Policy

You are a doctor in a health clinic overrun by patients with the latest flu virus. You just received a shipment of drugs that can cure the flu but the drugs have their own severe sideeffects. If you administer the drugs to your patients, a small number will die from the side effects but most will live.
If you do not, most will continue to suffer from the effects of the flu virus for some time. Is it appropriate for you to administer the drug to your patients?
17 Incongruent Animal Research

You have been hired by a pharmaceutical company to conduct research on their products. Since products must be fit for human use, they are first tried out on animals. Your job is to find out the effects various chemicals have on rats, pigeons, rabbits, and monkeys. Most chemicals have only minor effects on the animals, but some cause them discomfort or even permanent damage. The chemicals you are researching are slated to form part of a new AIDS drug cocktail that will give new hope to millions of AIDS victims around the world. You anticipate saving many lives with the chemicals. Is it appropriate to test these chemicals on animals?
18 Congruent Animal Research

You have been hired by a pharmaceutical company to conduct research on their products. Since products must be fit for human use, they are first tried out on animals. Your job is to find out the effects various chemicals have on rats, pigeons, rabbits, and monkeys. Most chemicals have only minor effects on the animals, but some cause them discomfort or even permanent damage. The chemicals you are researching are slated to form part of a new acne facial cleanser that will give new hope to people with pimples and greasy skin. You anticipate making many people feel better about their appearance with the chemicals. Is it appropriate to test these chemicals on animals?
19 Incongruent Border Crossing

You are a soldier guarding a border checkpoint between your nation and one troubled by insurgent violence. You notice a young man in a cheap car approaching the checkpoint with a determined look on his face. You suspect he means to bomb the checkpoint, killing all the soldiers inside. He is rapidly approaching your station. Is it appropriate for you to shoot and kill the approaching man?

20 Congruent Border Crossing You are a soldier guarding a border checkpoint between your nation and one troubled by insurgent violence. You notice a young man in a cheap car approaching the checkpoint with a determined look on his face. You suspect he means to cross the border in order to work illegally inside your country. He is rapidly approaching your station. Is it appropriate for you to shoot and kill the approaching man?
These are additional dilemmas we used to independently estimate deontology and utilitarianism via direct questions about the permissibility of action and of inaction.

div.head: Traditional trolley dilemmas
div.p: A trolley has broken out of control and is speeding down the tracks. In its path are five people tied to the tracks by a mad philosopher. The speeding trolley will kill them all. You can move the switch and thus direct the wagon to the other track, to which one man is tied. If the wagon runs over that track, it will kill that man.

To what extent is it morally acceptable, in your opinion, to... a) Pull the lever so that the trolley turns to the track with one man b) NOT to pull the lever, so that the trolley continues to speed along the track with five people.

A trolley has broken out of control and is speeding down the tracks. In its path are five people tied to the tracks by a mad philosopher. The speeding trolley will kill them all. You are on a footbridge over the tracks and can stop the wagon before it reaches the people tied to the tracks only by throwing something heavy from the footbridge onto the tracks. It just so happens that there is a very fat person next to you -the only way to stop the wagon is to push it off the footbridge onto the tracks.

To what extent is it morally acceptable, in your opinion, to... a) Push a fat man onto the tracks so as to stop a speeding wagon with his body? b) NOT to push the fat man onto the tracks, so that the wagon continues its momentum on the tracks? In order for the analyses below to work correctly, it is necessary that all responses of "No, I find this inappropriate" = 0 and "Yes, I find this appropriate" = 1 for all dilemmas.
*Depending on how you coded dilemma responses, you MAY need to recode.

*If you used the medialab file provided by Conway & Gawronski, you will need to recode in the following manner: RECODE D01IQ D02CQ D03IQ D04CQ D05IQ D06CQ D07IQ D08CQ D09IQ D10CQ D11IQ D12CQ D13IQ D14CQ D15IQ D16CQ D17IQ D18CQ D19IQ D20CQ (1=0) (2=1).

div.head: EXECUTE.
div.p: ***Step 2: Initial Calculations*** *Note that correctly calculating the parameters requires NO MISSING DATA for dilemma responses. If a participant answered fewer than all 20 dilemmas, they must be excluded.

*Note that occasionally there may be an error at this stage if someone's PD_utilitarian score is zero, as this would require division by zero. If this occurs, please exclude the participant with a PD_utilitarian score of 0.
COMPUTE perc_act_inc = MEAN(D01IQ, D03IQ, D05IQ, D07IQ, D09IQ, D11IQ, D13IQ, D15IQ, D17IQ, D19IQ).
COMPUTE perc_act_con = MEAN(D02CQ, D04CQ, D06CQ, D08CQ, D10CQ, D12CQ, D14CQ, D16CQ, D18CQ, D20CQ).
COMPUTE perc_inac_inc = 1 -perc_act_inc.
COMPUTE perc_inac_con = 1 -perc_act_con.
COMPUTE PD_utilitarian = perc_inac_con -perc_inac_inc.
COMPUTE PD_deontological = perc_inac_inc / (1 -PD_utilitarian).

div.head: EXECUTE.
div.p: ****Step 3: Exclusion (Optional)*** *If you decide to exclude any participants (e.g., for failing a manipulation check) then you must restandardize the parameters before analysis. No other recalculations are necessary.

Step 4: Standardizing PD Parameters*** *In order to compare parameters across conditions, it is necessary to standardize them as they are on different metrics (see Appendix B in Conway & Gawronski, 2013, p. 235)

figure.figDesc: Conway, P., & Gawronski, B. (2013). Deontological and utilitarian inclinations in moral decision-making: A process dissociation approach. Journal ofPersonality and Social Psychology, 104, 216-235. doi:10.1037/a0031021 *Stimuli: 10 Moral Dilemmas, each with two versions: congruent and incongruent *Incongruent dilemmas correspond to traditional high-conflict moral dilemmas (seeKoenigs et al., 2007), pitting deontology against utilitarianism. *Congruent dilemmas are identically worded except for the benefits of harmful action in each dilemma, such that deontology and utilitarianism are no longer in conflict. *Recommended Dilemma Response Options: "Yes, I find this appropriate" or "No, I find this inappropriate" for each dilemma***********Guide to Variable Names********** *Note: Variable names correspond to the variable names employed by Conway & Gawronski's medialab version of the dilemma battery. *Note that the dilemma numbers also correspond to Appendix A in Conway & Gawronski, 2013, as well as to the dilemma numbers in Conway & Gawronski's Recommended Running Procedures document. *Hence, Dilemma 01 = Time Machine (Incongruent), Dilemma 02 = Time Machine (incongruent), Dilemma 03 = Car accident (Incongruent), etc. *D01IQ = Dilemma 01, Incongruent Question *D02CQ = Dilemma 01, Congruent Question *D03IQ = Dilemma 03, Incongruent Question *D04CQ = Dilemma 04, Congruent Question, etc... *perc_act_inc = Percentage of harmful action accepted for incongruent dilemmas (analogous to raw utilitarian judgments using traditional analysis) *perc_act_con = Percentage of harmful action accepted for congruent dilemmas *perc_inac_inc = Percentage of harmful action rejected for incongruent dilemmas (analogous to raw deontological judgments using traditional analysis) *perc_inac_con = Percentage of harmful action rejected for congruent dilemmas *PD_utilitarian = Utilitarian Parameter *PD_deontological = Deontology Parameter *zPD_utilitarian = Standardized Utilitarian Parameter *zPD_deontological = Standardized Deontology Parameter *Condition = code for which condition participants were in (e.g., 1 = cognitive load, 2 = control) *Score = name for the within-subjects variable created during repeated measures analysis. There are two levels of this variable: one for PD_utilitarian and one for PD_deontological scores. *D01IH = Dilemma 01, Incongruent Hardness (i.e., dilemma difficulty), etc... *Dilemma difficulty ratings are OPTIONAL manipulation checks to examine whether participants perceive incongruent dilemmas as more difficult than congruent ones, on average. *Difficulty_Incongruent = Mean dilemma difficulty rating across incongruent dilemmas *Difficulty_Congruent = Mean dilemma difficulty rating across congruent dilemmas

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Comparisons between pre-and post-treatment for D and U-parameters, along with the traditional score for utilitarian decisions in incongruent scenarios, for N = 107.

0.50], p < .001.However, the U-parameter did not correlate with judging the permissibility of an action in the footbridge dilemma, r(194) = 0.04[-.10, 0.18], p = .600, and only modestly in the switch dilemma, r(194) = 0.18[.04, .31], p = .011. the D-parameter did not correlate with judging permissibility of inaction in the footbridge dilemma, r(194) = -0.01[-.15, 0.13], p = .864, and in the switch dilemma, r(194) = -0.02[-.16, 0.12], p = .772. In short, the exploratory and simplified measure of deontological and utilitarian inclination proposed byBostyn (e.g., Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Xu et al., 2024) does not appear to capture the same construct as D
figure.note: Mpre = 80.50 SD = 17.80, Mpost = 170.10, SD = 22.30, t(89) = -33.20, p < .001, d = -3.50 [- 4.04, -2.94], showing that our manipulation did influence the physiological state of the participants.and U-parameters estimated using the Process Dissociation method.

figure.figDesc: Our results indicate that moral judgments are not as easily affected by external factors, such as fatigue. This is consistent with prior literature that reported mixed effects of experimental manipulations inducing physical or cognitive fatigue.Of course, our findings are not definitive. Every experiment has a probabilistic chance of detecting a true effect, contingent on both the effect size and sample size. Our samples, while larger than previous studies in this domain, still had limitations. Both experiments comprised primarily fit, athletic males, which may have diminished the impact of acute physical exertion compared to individuals unaccustomed to regular exercise. Additionally, participants completed other measures (e.g., disgust sensitivity assessments) before responding to moral dilemmas. Although the presentation order was standardized within each experiment, it

row.cell: differed between studies, potentially introducing confounding variables. Furthermore, while
our Process Dissociation approach represents a significant methodological advancement over
traditional moral dilemma paradigms by separating deontological from utilitarian inclinations,
In most of the we did not account for action aversion-a third critical factor. People may select passive
tests, Bayesian analysis suggests our data is more likely under the null model than the options (i.e., inaction) not because they judge them as morally superior, but because inaction
alternative, and for the remaining tests, it classifies the studies as inconclusive. In other
words, Bayesian analyses in the two studies never supports the alternative model. This holds
for traditional measures (such as trolley problem scenarios), for distinct deontological (D) and
utilitarian (U) parameters, and for exploratory measures of moral inclinations. The estimates
of D and U-parameters broaden our conclusion, overcoming the limitations of traditional
scoring which cannot separately assess deontological and utilitarian responses (Conway &
Gawronski, 2013). For example, a scenario causing a slight decrease in deontological
inclination and a greater decrease in utilitarian inclination would, under traditional scoring,
erroneously appear as an increase in deontological choices due to the scoring's emphasis on
the relative strength of the two inclinations.

body.note: Because of the ethical problems, we were only allowed to test male participants. Thus, the preregistration was not followed in full.

As suggested by the reviewer, repeated-measures ANOVA may be more suitable for that type of analysis. However, also this approach yielded non -significant main effect of fatigue F(1,104) < 1, p = .790, and of fatigue by moral inclination type interaction, F(1,104) < 1, p = .950.3 These priors correspond to a probability of 50% that the effect size (in Cohen's d) under the null hypothesis being true lies between -0.707 to +0.707. This is a conservative test, often supporting null hypothesis when the true studied effect is small(Simonsohn, 2015).

We ran ANOVA again for this analysis. Consistently with t-tests, this analysis yielded non -significant main effect of fatigue F(1,194) = 3.11, p = .079, and of fatigue by moral inclination type interaction, F(1,194) < 2.25, p = .135.

div.head: Supplementary Materials:
div.p: Below is the full list of Dilemmas from Conway & Gawronski (2013). We crossed scenarios that we decided to remove due to them not working well in the Polish sample.
